'''Travis Michael Kelce''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|ɛ|l|s|i|audio=En-us-Kelce.ogg}} {{respell|KEL|see}};{{efn|Kelce has stated that he pronounces his last name {{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|ɛ|l|s|i}} {{respell|KEL|see}}, as that is how his father pronounces it, although the rest of his father's side of the family pronounces it {{IPAc-en|k|ɛ|l|s}} {{respell|KELSS}}.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Rivera |first=Joe |date=July 16, 2021 |title=Travis Kelce continues to confuse everyone when it comes to his name pronunciation |url=https://www.sportingnews.com/us/nfl/news/travis-kelce-confuses-every-name-pronunciation/1b7nkt8rgopz018otwxv0o3ony |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220128145733/https://www.sportingnews.com/us/nfl/news/travis-kelce-confuses-every-name-pronunciation/1b7nkt8rgopz018otwxv0o3ony |archive-date=January 28, 2022 |access-date=July 28, 2021 |website=Sporting News |quote=I say /ˈkɛlsi/ because that's what my father says.}}</ref> Kelce's brother, Jason, later elaborated that their father "at some point ... got tired of correcting everyone calling him 'Kell-see.' ... And now I think we're both at the point where we're riding with Ed 'Kell-see{{'"}}.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Zangaro |first=Dave |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Jason Kelce helps solve recent mystery about pronunciation of last name |url=https://www.nbcsports.com/philadelphia/eagles/eagles-jason-kelce-clears-how-pronounce-his-last-name |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211211213808/https://www.nbcsports.com/philadelphia/eagles/eagles-jason-kelce-clears-how-pronounce-his-last-name |archive-date=December 11, 2021 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=RSN |language=en}}</ref>}} born October 5, 1989) is an [[American football]] [[tight end]] for the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). He was drafted by the Chiefs in the third round of the [[2013 NFL Draft]] and later won Super Bowls [[Super Bowl LIV|LIV]] and [[Super Bowl LVII|LVII]] with the team, catching a [[touchdown]] in both wins. He played [[college football]] for the [[Cincinnati Bearcats football|Cincinnati Bearcats]].

Considered one of the greatest tight ends of all time,<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 11, 2022 |title=Where Travis Kelce stands among the greatest tight ends of all time |url=https://www.foxsports.com/stories/nfl/where-travis-kelce-stands-among-the-greatest-tight-ends-of-all-time |access-date=January 8, 2023 |website=FOX Sports}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Kerr |first=Jeff |date=December 3, 2022 |title=Is Travis Kelce the best TE of all time? Where Chiefs star compares to all-time greats at the position |url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/is-travis-kelce-the-best-te-of-all-time-where-chiefs-star-compares-to-all-time-greats-at-the-position/ |access-date=January 8, 2023 |website=CBSSports.com}}</ref> Kelce is an eight-time [[Pro Bowl]]er and a four-time first-team [[All-Pro]] selection. He holds the NFL record for most consecutive and most overall seasons with 1,000 yards [[Reception (gridiron football)|receiving]] by a tight end with seven.<ref name="10,000 yards"/> He also owns the record for most receiving yards by a tight end in a single season with 1,416 in 2020, despite playing in only 15 games.<ref name="Reception record"/><ref name="Receptions"/> He also briefly held the single season record in 2018 before it was broken later that same day. During the 2022 season, Kelce became the fastest tight end to reach 10,000 career receiving yards, and he became the fifth tight end in NFL history to reach the milestone.<ref name="10,000 yards"/> Kelce was named to the [[National Football League 2010s All-Decade Team|NFL 2010s All-Decade Team]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Scott |first=J.P. |date=June 21, 2022 |title=25 Greatest Tight Ends in NFL History |url=https://athlonsports.com/nfl/25-greatest-tight-ends-nfl-history |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220809220024/https://athlonsports.com/nfl/25-greatest-tight-ends-nfl-history |archive-date=August 9, 2022 |access-date=August 9, 2022 |website=Athlon Sports}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Fragoza |first=James |date=October 24, 2021 |title=13 greatest tight ends of all time from Tony Gonzalez to Jackie Smith |url=https://www.profootballnetwork.com/ranking-top-tight-ends-in-nfl-history/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220809220404/https://www.profootballnetwork.com/ranking-top-tight-ends-in-nfl-history/ |archive-date=August 9, 2022 |access-date=August 9, 2022 |website=Pro Football Network}}</ref>

Outside of football, Kelce has appeared on reality and scripted television and in advertisements. He co-hosts the podcast ''New Heights'' with his brother [[Jason Kelce|Jason]], covering topics from football to popular culture. Kelce's jersey sales and celebrity coverage increased following publicity of a relationship with singer [[Taylor Swift]].

==Early life==
Kelce was born on October 5, 1989, in [[Westlake, Ohio]]. His father, Ed Kelce, is a sales representative in the steel industry, and his mother, Donna, is a former bank executive. Kelce's older brother, [[Jason Kelce]], is also a professional football player who plays center for the [[Philadelphia Eagles]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=McManus |first=Tim |date=February 22, 2020 |title=Sibling fights to Super Bowls: Kelce boys have always been life of party |url=https://www.espn.com/blog/philadelphia-eagles/post/_/id/29128/sibling-fights-to-super-bowls-kelce-boys-have-always-been-life-of-party |access-date=September 22, 2023 |website=ESPN.com |language=en}}</ref>

Kelce attended [[Cleveland Heights High School]] in his hometown of [[Cleveland Heights, Ohio]], where he was a three-sport athlete in [[high school football|football]], [[high school basketball|basketball]], and [[baseball]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Greene |first=Dan |date=October 18, 2017 |title=That's So Travis: Chiefs' Star TE Not Afraid To Be Himself |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/10/18/travis-kelce-kansas-city-chiefs |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123075222/https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/10/18/travis-kelce-kansas-city-chiefs |archive-date=January 23, 2018 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |magazine=Sports Illustrated}}</ref> Excelling at football, he was a three-year letter winner as [[quarterback]] for the Tigers, and recognized with All-[[Lake Erie League]] honors after totaling 2,539 yards of total offense as a senior.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Mosby |first=Chris |date=October 3, 2017 |title=CHUH Alum, NFL Star Travis Kelce Shouts Out Alma Mater |url=https://patch.com/ohio/clevelandheights/chuh-alum-nfl-star-travis-kelce-shouts-out-alma-mater |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180402035532/https://patch.com/ohio/clevelandheights/chuh-alum-nfl-star-travis-kelce-shouts-out-alma-mater |archive-date=April 2, 2018 |access-date=April 1, 2018 |website=Cleveland Heights, OH Patch}}</ref> He ran 1,016 rushing yards and 10 rushing touchdowns, threw for 1,523 passing yards, 21 touchdowns, and eight interceptions in 2007.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Setter |first=Aidan |date=September 22, 2015 |title=Kansas City Chiefs: Travis Kelce In The Spotlight |url=https://kckingdom.com/2015/09/22/kansas-city-chiefs-travis-kelce-spotlight/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190223020431/https://kckingdom.com/2015/09/22/kansas-city-chiefs-travis-kelce-spotlight/ |archive-date=February 23, 2019 |access-date=February 22, 2019 |website=KC Kingdom}}</ref>

==College career==
Considered a two-star recruit by [[Rivals.com]], Kelce accepted a scholarship offer from the [[University of Cincinnati]] over offers from [[University of Akron|Akron]], [[Eastern Michigan University|Eastern Michigan]], and [[Miami University|Miami (OH)]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce |url=https://n.rivals.com/content/prospects/2008/travis-kelce-12204 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010210434/https://n.rivals.com/content/prospects/2008/travis-kelce-12204 |archive-date=October 10, 2017 |access-date=October 10, 2017 |website=n.rivals.com}}</ref> He joined his brother, Jason Kelce, who was the starting left guard for the [[Cincinnati Bearcats football|Bearcats]]. After [[Redshirt (college sports)|redshirting]] in 2008, he appeared in 11 games, playing at tight end and quarterback out of the [[Wildcat formation]]. He tallied eight rushes for 47 yards and two touchdowns along with one reception for three yards in 2009.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2009 Game Log |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/travis-kelce-1/gamelog/2009/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125134609/https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/travis-kelce-1/gamelog/2009/ |archive-date=January 25, 2018 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com}}</ref> The following season, he did not play due to a violation of team rules, which was later revealed to be failing a drug test by testing positive for marijuana.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 24, 2019 |title=Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce continues to grow and evolve |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2019/12/24/chiefs-tight-end-travis-kelce-continues-to-grow-and-evolve/40885457/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200524060812/https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2019/12/24/chiefs-tight-end-travis-kelce-continues-to-grow-and-evolve/40885457/ |archive-date=May 24, 2020 |access-date=November 4, 2020 |website=USA TODAY |language=en-US |agency=Associated Press}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Pawlowski |first=Justin |date=February 23, 2013 |title=NFL Draft: TE Travis Kelce's Character Concerns |url=http://tampa.cbslocal.com/2013/02/23/nfl-draft-te-travis-kelces-character-concerns/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926003146/http://tampa.cbslocal.com/2013/02/23/nfl-draft-te-travis-kelces-character-concerns/ |archive-date=September 26, 2015 |access-date=September 9, 2015 |website=CBS Tampa Bay}}</ref> After serving a one-year suspension, Kelce was back with the team to start the 2011 season. For the season, he saw action in games as a tight end and recorded 13 catches totaling 150 yards and two touchdowns.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2011 Game Log |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/travis-kelce-1/gamelog/2011 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170724085417/https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/travis-kelce-1/gamelog/2011/ |archive-date=July 24, 2017 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com}}</ref> In his last collegiate season, he set personal career highs in receptions (45), receiving yards (722), yards per receptions (16.0), and receiving touchdowns (8), he also earned first-team all-conference honors.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2012 Game Log |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/travis-kelce-1/gamelog/2012 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125074626/https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/travis-kelce-1/gamelog/2012 |archive-date=January 25, 2018 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com}}</ref> In March 2013, Kelce was named winner of the College Football Performance Awards Tight End of the Year for 2012.<ref>{{Cite web |title=2012 CFPA TIGHT END TROPHY |url=http://collegefootballperformance.com/offensive-awards/tight-end/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150813170149/http://collegefootballperformance.com/offensive-awards/tight-end/ |archive-date=August 13, 2015 |access-date=September 9, 2015 |website=College Football Performance Awards}}</ref> Kelce graduated in 2022 with a Bachelor of Interdisciplinary Studies degree.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kern |first1=Jac |title=Everything you need to know about UC alum Travis Kelce |url=https://www.uc.edu/news/articles/2023/09/who-is-travis-kelce.html |website=UC News |language=en-us |date=September 29, 2023}}</ref>

===2013 season===
{{See also|2013 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
Kelce was drafted by the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] in the third round (63rd pick overall) of the [[2013 NFL Draft]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |date=April 26, 2013 |title=Chiefs draft TE Kelce, RB Davis in NFL Draft's third round |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2013/04/26/4204793/chiefs-draft-tight-end-travis.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130430205451/http://www.kansascity.com/2013/04/26/4204793/chiefs-draft-tight-end-travis.html |archive-date=April 30, 2013 |access-date=September 9, 2015 |website=Kansas City Star}}</ref> The Chiefs had hired [[Andy Reid]] as their new head coach during the off-season. Reid was familiar with Kelce after he had drafted and coached his brother, Jason Kelce, in 2011 during his time as the head coach of the Eagles.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs Coaches |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/coaches.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180402105712/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/coaches.htm |archive-date=April 2, 2018 |access-date=April 1, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Thorman |first=Joel |date=April 27, 2013 |title=Chief's draft picks 2013:5 things you need to know about Travis Kelce |url=http://www.arrowheadpride.com/platform/amp/2013/4/27/4273998/chiefs-draft-picks-2013-travis-kelce |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202045716/http://www.arrowheadpride.com/platform/amp/2013/4/27/4273998/chiefs-draft-picks-2013-travis-kelce |archive-date=February 2, 2017 |access-date=November 6, 2016 |website=arrowheadpride.com}}</ref> On June 6, 2013, the Chiefs signed Kelce to a four-year, $3.12 million rookie contract that also included a signing bonus of $703,304.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Sportrac.com: Travis Kelce contracts |url=http://www.spotrac.com/nfl/kansas-city-chiefs/travis-kelce-12344/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161030075008/http://www.spotrac.com/nfl/kansas-city-chiefs/travis-kelce-12344/ |archive-date=October 30, 2016 |access-date=October 29, 2016 |website=sportrac.com}}</ref> 

Kelce injured his knee in the preseason. The injury was later diagnosed as a bone bruise. After being limited the first two weeks of the season due to the injury and being inactive the next 3 games, Kelce was placed on injured reserve on October 12, 2013, after having a microfracture surgery performed on his knee.<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 12, 2013 |title=Chiefs place tight end Travis Kelce on injured reserve |url=https://www.nbcsports.com/nfl/profootballtalk/rumor-mill/news/chiefs-place-tight-end-travis-kelce-on-injured-reserve |access-date=October 24, 2023 |website=NBC Sports |language=en-US}}</ref> He only played one snap on special teams in the Chiefs' Week 2 game against the [[Dallas Cowboys]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Dallas Cowboys at Kansas City Chiefs – September 15th, 2013 Box Score |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201309150kan.htm |access-date=September 2, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref>

===2014 season===
[[File:Travis Kelce.JPG|thumb|225px|Kelce in 2014]]
{{See also|2014 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
During Week 3 against the [[Miami Dolphins]], Kelce recorded his first NFL touchdown on a 20-yard reception from quarterback [[Alex Smith]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs at Miami Dolphins – September 21st, 2014 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201409210mia.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190801195125/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201409210mia.htm |archive-date=August 1, 2019 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> On November 30, he was fined $11,025 for "unsportsmanlike conduct" during a 29–16 loss to the [[Denver Broncos]]. Kelce made an inappropriate hand gesture and motion at the Broncos linebacker [[Von Miller]]. Chiefs head coach Andy Reid later called this "immature".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |date=December 6, 2014 |title=Travis Kelce fined $11K for gesture |url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/11984128/travic-kelce-kansas-city-chiefs-fined-11025-gesture |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151204141545/http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/11984128/travic-kelce-kansas-city-chiefs-fined-11025-gesture |archive-date=December 4, 2015 |access-date=September 9, 2015 |website=ESPN.com}}</ref> In the next game against the [[Arizona Cardinals]], Kelce had seven receptions for 110 yards for his first NFL game with over 100 receiving yards.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs at Arizona Cardinals – December 7th, 2014 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201412070crd.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125134504/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201412070crd.htm |archive-date=January 25, 2018 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> In the regular-season finale against the [[San Diego Chargers]], he had an offensive fumble recovery for a touchdown in the 19–7 victory.<ref>{{Cite web |title=San Diego Chargers at Kansas City Chiefs – December 28th, 2014 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201412280kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108032549/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201412280kan.htm |archive-date=November 8, 2017 |access-date=April 1, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> Kelce was the Chiefs' leading receiver during the 2014 season, totaling 862 yards off 67 receptions.<ref>{{Cite web |title=2014 Kansas City Chiefs Statistics & Players |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/2014.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171115015504/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/2014.htm |archive-date=November 15, 2017 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref>

===2015 season===
{{See also|2015 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
Kelce began the 2015 season with his first NFL multiple touchdown game, with six receptions for 106 yards and two touchdowns in the 27–20 victory over the [[Houston Texans]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs at Houston Texans – September 13th, 2015 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201509130htx.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180111170752/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201509130htx.htm |archive-date=January 11, 2018 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> It was his only 100-plus-yard game, but he had at least one reception in all 16 games,<ref name="glog">{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce Career Game Log - Pro-Football-Reference.com |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220421224155/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/ |archive-date=April 21, 2022 |access-date=September 2, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> and was ranked a top-five tight end by ESPN.<ref>{{Cite web |date=May 12, 2015 |title=Fantasy football: TE rankings for 2015 |url=https://www.espn.com/fantasy/football/story/_/id/12872374/te-rankings-2015 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201111041912/https://www.espn.com/fantasy/football/story/_/id/12872374/te-rankings-2015 |archive-date=November 11, 2020 |access-date=November 4, 2020 ===2016 season===
{{See also|2016 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
On January 29, 2016, Kelce signed a five-year, $46 million contract extension.<ref>{{Cite web |date=January 29, 2016 |title=Kelce signs rich contract extension with Chiefs |url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14672784/travis-kelce-agrees-contract-extension-kansas-city-chiefs |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130092657/http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14672784/travis-kelce-agrees-contract-extension-kansas-city-chiefs |archive-date=January 30, 2016 |access-date=January 30, 2016 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> He was ranked 91st by his fellow players on the [[NFL Top 100 Players of 2016]].<ref name="auto"/>

During Week 8 against the [[Indianapolis Colts]], Kelce had seven receptions for 101 yards and a touchdown.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs at Indianapolis Colts – October 30th, 2016 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201610300clt.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125134500/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201610300clt.htm |archive-date=January 25, 2018 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> In the next game against the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]], he was ejected after receiving two unsportsmanlike conduct penalties after arguing with two officials over not having a pass interference penalty called.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Shook |first=Nick |date=November 6, 2016 |title=Travis Kelce ejected from Chief's game after tirade |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000734522/article/travis-kelce-ejected-from-chiefs-game-after-tirade |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161107093040/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000734522/article/travis-kelce-ejected-from-chiefs-game-after-tirade |archive-date=November 7, 2016 |access-date=November 6, 2016 |website=NFL.com}}</ref> The second resulted from him sarcastically throwing his towel at field judge Mike Weatherford in a flagging motion due to being upset about the first penalty. He was later fined $24,309 for his outburst.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Bergman |first=Jeremy |date=November 11, 2016 |title=Travis Kelce fined 24K for Unsportsmanlike Conduct |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000737677/article/travis-kelce-fined-24k-for-unsportsmanlike-conduct |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161112145422/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000737677/article/travis-kelce-fined-24k-for-unsportsmanlike-conduct |archive-date=November 12, 2016 |access-date=November 11, 2016 |website=NFL.com}}</ref> During Week 13 against the [[Atlanta Falcons]], he had eight receptions for 140 yards.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs at Atlanta Falcons – December 4th, 2016 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201612040atl.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171210071930/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201612040atl.htm |archive-date=December 10, 2017 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> In the next game, Kelce recorded 101 receiving yards against the [[Oakland Raiders]], his fourth consecutive game topping 100.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Oakland Raiders at Kansas City Chiefs – December 8th, 2016 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201612080kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125134506/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201612080kan.htm |archive-date=January 25, 2018 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> He joined [[Jimmy Graham]] and former Chiefs tight end [[Tony Gonzalez]] as the only NFL tight ends ever to do so.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |date=December 9, 2016 |title=Travis Kelce joins Tony Gonzalez in Chiefs' receiving record book |url=http://www.espn.com/blog/nflnation/post/_/id/224056/travis-kelce-joins-tony-gonzalez-in-chiefs-receiving-record-book |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190402074522/http://www.espn.com/blog/nflnation/post/_/id/224056/travis-kelce-joins-tony-gonzalez-in-chiefs-receiving-record-book |archive-date=April 2, 2019 |access-date=December 2, 2020 |website=ESPN.com}}</ref> In a Christmas Day win over the Broncos, Kelce had career bests of 11 receptions for 160 yards and a career-long 80-yard touchdown on a screen pass.<ref name="glog"/> He finished the season with career highs in yards (1,125) and receptions (85).<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2016 Game Log |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/2016 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125134440/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/2016 |archive-date=January 25, 2018 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> His 1,125 receiving yards led the league among tight ends and his 85 receptions were second among tight ends behind [[Dennis Pitta]] of the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. Kelce's 634 yards after the catch also led all NFL tight ends.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce Advanced Stats and Metrics Profile: Yards After The Catch |url=http://www.playerprofiler.com/nfl/travis-kelce |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201111205351/https://www.playerprofiler.com/nfl/travis-kelce/ |archive-date=November 11, 2020 |access-date=December 2, 2020 |website=PlayerProfiler.com}}</ref> He was named as a starter in his second career Pro Bowl, held on December 20, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 20, 2016 |title=NFL announces 2017 Pro Bowl rosters |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000760503/article/nfl-announces-2017-pro-bowl-rosters |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181117075658/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000760503/article/nfl-announces-2017-pro-bowl-rosters |archive-date=November 17, 2018 |access-date=December 2, 2020 |website=NFL.com}}</ref> He was also named First-team [[All-Pro]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=January 6, 2017 |title=Three rookies, Matt Ryan among players named to All-Pro team |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000770458/article/three-rookies-matt-ryan-among-players-named-to-allpro-team?campaign=Twitter_atn |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201221191219/https://www.nfl.com/news/three-rookies-matt-ryan-among-players-named-to-all-pro-team-0ap3000000770458 |archive-date=December 21, 2020 |website=NFL.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> He was ranked 26th by his fellow players, and second among tight ends, on the [[NFL Top 100 Players of 2017]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=2017 NFL Top 100 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2017-nfl-top-100.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220511024213/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2017-nfl-top-100.htm |archive-date=May 11, 2022 |access-date=January 12, 2021 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref>

The Chiefs finished atop the [[AFC West]] with a 12–4 record and earned a first-round bye in the playoffs.<ref>{{Cite web |title=2016 NFL Standings & Team Stats |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2016 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180329001215/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2016/ |archive-date=March 29, 2018 |access-date=January 31, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> In the [[2016–17 NFL playoffs#AFC: Pittsburgh Steelers 18, Kansas City Chiefs 16|Divisional Round]] against the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], Kelce had five receptions for 77 yards in the 18–16 loss.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Divisional Round – Pittsburgh Steelers at Kansas City Chiefs – January 15th, 2017 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201701150kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180106173254/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201701150kan.htm |archive-date=January 6, 2018 |access-date=January 31, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref>

The 10–6 Chiefs<ref>{{Cite web |title=2017 Kansas City Chiefs Statistics & Players |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/2017.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180126205533/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/kan/2017.htm |archive-date=January 26, 2018 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> entered the [[2017–18 NFL playoffs#AFC: Tennessee Titans 22, Kansas City Chiefs 21|Wild Card Round]] of the playoffs against the [[Tennessee Titans]], where Kelce finished with four receptions for 66 yards and a touchdown in the 21–22 defeat.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Wild Card – Tennessee Titans at Kansas City Chiefs – January 6th, 2018 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201801060kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180110052938/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201801060kan.htm |archive-date=January 10, 2018 |access-date=January 24, 2018 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> He was not able to finish the game as he suffered a concussion in the first half on a hit to his helmet.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Rapaport |first=Daniel |date=January 6, 2018 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce suffered concussion vs. Titans |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/01/06/travis-kelce-chiefs-titans-locker-room-head-injury-concussion |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180402101520/https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/01/06/travis-kelce-chiefs-titans-locker-room-head-injury-concussion |archive-date=April 2, 2018 |access-date=April 1, 2018 |magazine=Sports Illustrated}}</ref>

===2018 season===
{{See also|2018 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
In the 2018 season, Kelce benefited from the rise of new quarterback [[Patrick Mahomes]], who was named [[NFL MVP]] at the end of the season.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Benoit |first=Andy |date=August 24, 2018 |title=Chiefs preview: Andy Reid ready to let Mahomes loose? |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/08/24/kansas-city-chiefs-2018-nfl-team-preview |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181005194950/https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/08/24/kansas-city-chiefs-2018-nfl-team-preview |archive-date=October 5, 2018 |access-date=October 5, 2018 |magazine=Sports Illustrated}}</ref> After being held to a lone reception for six yards in the season opener against the Chargers, he rebounded with seven receptions for 106 yards and two touchdowns in a Week 2 road victory over the Steelers.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dulle |first=Brian |date=September 16, 2018 |title=Mahomes throws 6 TDs, Chiefs hold off Steelers 42–37 |work=FOX 4 Kansas City WDAF-TV |url=https://fox4kc.com/2018/09/16/chiefs-defeat-steelers-42-37-now-2-0-for-the-season/ |url-status=live |access-date=October 5, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181005194723/https://fox4kc.com/2018/09/16/chiefs-defeat-steelers-42-37-now-2-0-for-the-season/ |archive-date=October 5, 2018}}</ref> In two of the next three games, he was able to reach 100 receiving yards against the [[San Francisco 49ers]] and the Jaguars.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Rimpson |first=Robert |date=September 23, 2018 |title=Chiefs' players of the game Week 3 vs. 49ers |work=USA Today |url=https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2018/09/23/chiefs-players-of-the-game-week-3-vs-49ers/ |url-status=live |access-date=November 1, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181231194158/https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2018/09/23/chiefs-players-of-the-game-week-3-vs-49ers/ |archive-date=December 31, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=October 7, 2018 |title=Chiefs' Travis Kelce: Tallies 100 yards |url=https://www.cbssports.com/fantasy/football/news/chiefs-travis-kelce-tallies-100-yards/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190101041422/https://www.cbssports.com/fantasy/football/news/chiefs-travis-kelce-tallies-100-yards/ |archive-date=January 1, 2019 |access-date=November 1, 2018 |website=CBSSports.com}}</ref> He added 99 yards and two touchdowns in a Week 9 win over the [[Cleveland Browns]], and went into the Week 12 bye with 10 receptions for 127 yards and a touchdown in [[2018 Kansas City Chiefs–Los Angeles Rams game|an offensively spectacular 54–51 loss]] to the [[Los Angeles Rams]]. In the Week 13 win over the Raiders, Kelce had career-bests of 12 receptions and 168 yards, including two short touchdowns in the first half.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs at Oakland Raiders – December 2nd, 2018 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201812020rai.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181211010403/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201812020rai.htm |archive-date=December 11, 2018 |access-date=January 6, 2019 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> At this point, he was well on his way to an NFL record, but his production tapered off; over the final four weeks, Kelce averaged six receptions for 63.5 yards and had only one touchdown reception.<ref name="glog"/> In Week 17, Kelce indeed broke the NFL record for most receiving yards by a tight end in a single season, but 49ers tight end [[George Kittle]] passed him to claim the record less than an hour later.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Weinrib |first=Ben |date=December 31, 2018 |title=Travis Kelce broke the TE yardage record and lost it to George Kittle in less than an hour |url=https://www.yahoo.com/amphtml/sports/travis-kelce-broke-te-yardage-record-lost-george-kittle-less-hour-022504480.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190102130722/https://www.yahoo.com/amphtml/sports/travis-kelce-broke-te-yardage-record-lost-george-kittle-less-hour-022504480.html |archive-date=January 2, 2019 |access-date=October 22, 2020 |website=Yahoo Sports}}</ref> Kelce ended the regular season at 10th in the NFL in receptions with 103 and receiving yards with 1,336, and sixth in receiving touchdowns with 10.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2018 Game Log |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190223042817/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00.htm |archive-date=February 23, 2019 |access-date=February 22, 2019 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> He was named to the [[2018 Pro Bowl]] and was named first-team All-Pro.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teope |first=Herbie |date=January 4, 2019 |title=All-Pro Team: Donald, Mahomes among highlights |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000001007645/article/allpro-team-patrick-mahomes-among-2018-highlights |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190807044014/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000001007645/article/allpro-team-patrick-mahomes-among-2018-highlights |archive-date=August 7, 2019 |access-date=October 22, 2020 |website=NFL.com}}</ref>

The Chiefs finished atop the AFC West with a 12–4 record and earned a first-round bye.<ref>{{Cite web |title=2018 NFL Standings & Team Stats |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2018/index.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190320205744/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2018/index.htm |archive-date=March 20, 2019 |access-date=February 22, 2019 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> In the [[2018–19 NFL playoffs#AFC: Kansas City Chiefs 31, Indianapolis Colts 13|Divisional Round]] against the Colts, he had seven receptions for 108 yards in the 31–13 victory.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Divisional Round – Indianapolis Colts at Kansas City Chiefs – January 12th, 2019 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201901120kan.htm |url-status=live 23 yards and a receiving touchdown in the 37–31 overtime loss.<ref>{{Cite web |title=AFC Championship – New England Patriots at Kansas City Chiefs – January 20th, 2019 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201901200kan.htm |url-status=live ===2019 season: First Super Bowl win===
{{See also|2019 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
During Week 2 against the Raiders, Kelce caught seven passes for 107 yards and a touchdown of the season as the Chiefs won by a score of 28–10.<ref>{{Cite web |date=September 15, 2019 |title=Mahomes' 4 TDs in 2nd quarter lead Chiefs past Raiders 28–10 |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401128118 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200118172408/https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401128118 |archive-date=January 18, 2020 |access-date=September 15, 2019 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> Despite injuries to Patrick Mahomes and just two touchdowns, at the midpoint of the season Kelce led all tight ends and Chiefs players in receiving yards with 604.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tight ends with at least 500 receiving yards through eight games, NFL history |url=http://pfref.com/tiny/2rkLx |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191107200549/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/play-index/tiny.fcgi?id=2rkLx |archive-date=November 7, 2019 |access-date=May 27, 2020 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Chiefs receiving through eight games, 2012–2019 seasons |url=http://pfref.com/tiny/YGdTT |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191107200546/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/play-index/tiny.fcgi?id=YGdTT |archive-date=November 7, 2019 |access-date=May 27, 2020 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> During Week 11 against the Chargers on ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' in Mexico, Kelce caught seven passes for 92 yards and a touchdown in the 24–17 win.<ref>{{Cite web |date=November 18, 2019 |title=Mahomes, Chiefs hold off Chargers 24–17 in Mexico City |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401128134 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200709100906/https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401128134 |archive-date=July 9, 2020 |access-date=November 18, 2019 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> During Week 14 against the Patriots, Kelce caught seven passes for 66 yards and rushed the ball once for a one-yard touchdown during the 23–16 road victory.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 8, 2019 |title=KC survives mistakes, take AFC West with 23–13 win over Pats |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401127930 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191210192344/https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401127930 |archive-date=December 10, 2019 |access-date=December 8, 2019 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> In the next game against the Broncos, Kelce finished with 11 catches for 142 receiving yards as the Chiefs won 23–3.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 15, 2019 |title=Chiefs roll to 23–3 victory over Broncos at snowy Arrowhead |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401128056 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191217230828/https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401128056 |archive-date=December 17, 2019 |access-date=December 15, 2019 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> In the next game against the [[Chicago Bears]] on ''[[NBC Sunday Night Football|Sunday Night Football]]'', he caught eight passes for 74 yards and a touchdown in the 26–3 win. During the game, he became the fastest tight end in NFL history to record 500 career receptions.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 22, 2019 |title=Mahomes throws 2 TDs, runs for 1 as Chiefs beat Bears 26–3 |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401127943 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191223231647/https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401127943 |archive-date=December 23, 2019 |access-date=December 22, 2019 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref>

Kelce finished the 2019 season with 97 receptions for 1,229 receiving yards and five receiving touchdowns to go along with his one rushing touchdown.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2019 Game Log |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/2019/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200606032640/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/2019/ |archive-date=June 6, 2020 |access-date=January 30, 2020 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com}}</ref> Kelce became the first tight end in NFL history to record four consecutive seasons with at least 1,000 receiving yards.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Conner |first=Matt |date=December 15, 2019 |title=Travis Kelce becomes first tight end with 4 consecutive 1,000-yard seasons |url=https://arrowheadaddict.com/2019/12/15/travis-kelce-becomes-first-tight-end-4-consecutive-1000-yard-seasons/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220118182426/https://arrowheadaddict.com/2019/12/15/travis-kelce-becomes-first-tight-end-4-consecutive-1000-yard-seasons/ |archive-date=January 18, 2022 |access-date=January 30, 2020 |website=Arrowhead Addict}}</ref> He was named to his fifth Pro Bowl for his 2019 season.<ref>{{Cite web |title=2019 NFL Pro Bowlers |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2019/probowl.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220627030242/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2019/probowl.htm |archive-date=June 27, 2022 |access-date=September 2, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref>

In the [[2019–20 NFL playoffs#AFC: Kansas City Chiefs 51, Houston Texans 31|Divisional Round]] against the Texans, the Chiefs began the game with a 24–0 deficit. The Chiefs then went on a 51–7 run, including 41 unanswered points, to win 51–31. After a drop on third down on the Chiefs first drive that would have been a first down if it had been caught, Kelce caught 10 passes for 134 yards and three touchdowns (all in the second quarter) as he helped lead the Chiefs to their second consecutive conference championship game.<ref>{{Cite web |date=January 12, 2020 |title=Chiefs rally from 24–0 hole to beat Texans 51–31 in playoffs |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401131043 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200306163825/https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401131043 |archive-date=March 6, 2020 |access-date=January 12, 2020 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> In the [[2019–20 NFL playoffs#AFC Championship Game: Kansas City Chiefs 35, Tennessee Titans 24|AFC Championship Game]] against the Titans, Kelce caught three passes for 30 yards during the 35–24 win.<ref>{{Cite web |date=January 19, 2020 |title=Mahomes' feet, arms, lift Chiefs to Super Bowl over Titans |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401131044 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201222135813/https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401131044 |archive-date=December 22, 2020 |access-date=January 19, 2020 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> In [[Super Bowl LIV]] against the [[San Francisco 49ers]], Kelce caught six passes for 43 receiving yards and a receiving touchdown and had one carry for two rushing yards during the 31–20 win.<ref>{{Cite web |date=February 2, 2020 |title=Mahomes leads Chiefs' rally past 49ers in Super Bowl, 31–20 |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401131047 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210308041457/https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap?gameId=401131047 |archive-date=March 8, 2021 |access-date=February 2, 2020 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> He was ranked 18th by his fellow players on the [[NFL Top 100 Players of 2020]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=2020 NFL Top 100 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2020-nfl-top-100.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220408124719/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2020-nfl-top-100.htm |archive-date=April 8, 2022 |access-date=September 2, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref>

===2020 season===
{{See also|2020 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
Following the release of long-time Chiefs punter [[Dustin Colquitt]] in the offseason, Kelce became tied with [[Anthony Sherman]] and fellow 2013 draftee [[Eric Fisher (American football)|Eric Fisher]] as the longest tenured members of the Chiefs.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Conner |first=Matt |date=May 13, 2020 |title=Travis Kelce's growth as a leader now faces new challenge |url=https://arrowheadaddict.com/2020/05/13/travis-kelces-growth-leader-longest-tenured-chiefs/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200820124715/https://arrowheadaddict.com/2020/05/13/travis-kelces-growth-leader-longest-tenured-chiefs/ |archive-date=August 20, 2020 |access-date=September 17, 2020 |website=Arrowhead Addict |language=en-US}}</ref> On August 14, 2020, Kelce signed a four-year, $57 million contract extension with the Chiefs through the 2025 season.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Patra |first=Kevin |date=August 13, 2020 |title=Chiefs, TE Travis Kelce agree to terms on four-year, $57M extension |url=https://www.nfl.com/news/chiefs-travis-kelce-contract-extension |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200916104316/https://www.nfl.com/news/chiefs-travis-kelce-contract-extension |archive-date=September 16, 2020 |access-date=September 17, 2020 |website=NFL.com}}</ref> In Week 6, against the [[Buffalo Bills]], he recorded two receiving touchdowns in the 26–17 victory.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs at Buffalo Bills – October 19th, 2020 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202010190buf.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201020053723/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202010190buf.htm |archive-date=October 20, 2020 |access-date=October 22, 2020 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref> In Week 8 against the Jets, Kelce dunked the ball through the goal posts after scoring a touchdown, paying homage to former Chiefs tight end [[Tony Gonzalez]]. He was penalized for unsportsmanlike conduct and was fined $12,500.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teope |first=Herbie |date=November 7, 2020 |title=NFL dings Chiefs' Kelce $12,500 for unsportsmanlike conduct after his dunk on the Jets |url=https://www.kansascity.com/sports/nfl/kansas-city-chiefs/article247041557.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201111202203/https://www.kansascity.com/sports/nfl/kansas-city-chiefs/article247041557.html |archive-date=November 11, 2020 |access-date=November 13, 2020 |website=KansasCity.com}}</ref> In Week 9, against the [[Carolina Panthers]], he had ten receptions for 159 receiving yards in the 33–31 victory.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Carolina Panthers at Kansas City Chiefs – November 8th, 2020 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202011080kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201115121822/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202011080kan.htm |archive-date=November 15, 2020 |access-date=November 13, 2020 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref>  

In Week 11 against the [[Las Vegas Raiders]] on ''Sunday Night Football'', Kelce recorded eight catches for 127 yards including the game-winning touchdown during the 35–31 win.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs at Las Vegas Raiders – November 22nd, 2020 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202011220rai.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202085734/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202011220rai.htm |archive-date=December 2, 2020 |access-date=November 28, 2020 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref>
In Week 13 against the Broncos on ''Sunday Night Football'', Kelce recorded eight catches for 136 yards and a touchdown during the 22–16 win.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Denver Broncos at Kansas City Chiefs – December 6th, 2020 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202012060kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201127103220/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202012060kan.htm |archive-date=November 27, 2020 |access-date=December 8, 2020 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref> In the following game, he posted an identical statistical performance of eight catches for 136 yards and a touchdown against the Dolphins in a 33–27 victory.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Kansas City Chiefs at Miami Dolphins – December 13th, 2020 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202012130mia.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201127111907/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202012130mia.htm |archive-date=November 27, 2020 |access-date=December 18, 2020 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref> In Week 16, Kelce became the first tight end to have two 100-catch seasons.<ref name="Receptions"/><ref name="Reception record"/> Kelce caught seven passes, giving him a career-high 105 for the season. Kelce set the single-season yardage record for a tight end with 1,416, topping the 1,377 yards posted by [[George Kittle]] in 2018.<ref name="Receptions"/><ref name="Reception record"/><ref>{{Cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |date=December 27, 2020 |title=Kansas City Chiefs clinch No. 1 seed in AFC as Travis Kelce sets records |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/30607014/kansas-city-chiefs-clinch-no-1-seed-afc-travis-kelce-sets-records |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201228014551/https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/30607014/kansas-city-chiefs-clinch-no-1-seed-afc-travis-kelce-sets-records |archive-date=December 28, 2020 |access-date=December 28, 2020 |website=ESPN |language=en}}</ref> His yardage ranked second overall in the 2020 NFL season (behind [[Stefon Diggs]]' 1,535), while his total receptions ranked fifth in the NFL and second among tight ends (behind [[Darren Waller]]'s 107).<ref>{{Cite web |title=2020 Player Stats – Receiving |url=https://www.nfl.com/stats/player-stats/category/receiving/2020/REG/all/receivingreceptions/DESC |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210104083655/https://www.nfl.com/stats/player-stats/category/receiving/2020/REG/all/receivingreceptions/desc |archive-date=January 4, 2021 |access-date=January 5, 2021 |website=NFL.com |language=en}}</ref> He was named to his sixth Pro Bowl and earned First-team All-Pro honors.<ref>{{Cite web |title=2020 NFL Pro Bowlers |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2020/probowl.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220627025942/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2020/probowl.htm |archive-date=June 27, 2022 |access-date=September 2, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=2020 NFL All-Pros |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2020/allpro.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220619205501/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2020/allpro.htm |archive-date=June 19, 2022 |access-date=September 2, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref>

In the [[2020–21 NFL playoffs#AFC: Kansas City Chiefs 22, Cleveland Browns 17|Divisional Round of the playoffs]] against the Browns, Kelce recorded eight catches for 109 yards and a touchdown during the 22–17 win.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Divisional Round – Cleveland Browns at Kansas City Chiefs – January 17th, 2021 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202101170kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116103431/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202101170kan.htm |archive-date=January 16, 2021 |access-date=January 20, 2021 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref> In the [[2020–21 NFL playoffs#AFC: Kansas City Chiefs 38, Buffalo Bills 24|AFC Championship]] against the Bills, Kelce recorded 13 catches for 118 yards and two touchdowns in a 38–24 win to advance to [[Super Bowl LV]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=AFC Championship – Buffalo Bills at Kansas City Chiefs – January 24th, 2021 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202101240kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210130150035/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202101240kan.htm |archive-date=January 30, 2021 |access-date=January 31, 2021 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref> In the Super Bowl, despite Kelce catching 10 passes for 133 yards which set the record for most receiving yards by a tight end in a single Super Bowl, the Chiefs could not score a touchdown in the 31–9 loss to the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Junda |first=Zach |date=February 8, 2021 |title=White, Fournette Help Lead Bucs to Super Bowl 55 Win |url=https://www.andthevalleyshook.com/2021/2/8/22272150/white-fournette-help-lead-bucs-to-super-bowl-55-win |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210208141725/https://www.andthevalleyshook.com/2021/2/8/22272150/white-fournette-help-lead-bucs-to-super-bowl-55-win |archive-date=February 8, 2021 |access-date=February 8, 2021 |website=And The Valley Shook |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=February 8, 2021 |title=Travis Kelce: 133 receiving yards in the Chiefs' 31–9 loss vs. Tampa Bay. Most ever by a TE in a Super Bowl |url=https://twitter.com/pff/status/1358845834394284033 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210208183212/https://twitter.com/PFF/status/1358845834394284033 |archive-date=February 8, 2021 |access-date=March 4, 2021 |website=Twitter |publisher=PFF |language=en}}</ref> He was ranked fifth by his fellow players on the [[NFL Top 100 Players of 2021]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=2021 NFL Top 100 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2021-nfl-top-100.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211115200023/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2021-nfl-top-100.htm |archive-date=November 15, 2021 |access-date=September 2, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref>

===2021 season===
[[File:Cole Holcomb chasing Travis Kelce OCT2021 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|225px|Kelce playing against the [[Washington Football Team]] in 2021]]
{{See also|2021 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
Following the release of longtime Chiefs left tackle [[Eric Fisher (American football)|Eric Fisher]] and retirement of longtime fullback [[Anthony Sherman]] in the offseason, Kelce became the longest-tenured member of the Chiefs.<ref name=":0"/> In the Chiefs second game of the season against the Ravens, he become the fastest tight end in NFL history to record 8,000 career yards, surpassing [[Rob Gronkowski]]'s record in 113 games.<ref name="8000 yards">{{Cite web |last=Palmer |first=Tod |date=September 20, 2021 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce continues to build Hall of Fame résumé against Ravens |url=https://www.kshb.com/sports/kelce-continues-to-build-hall-of-fame-resume-against-ravens |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211017004030/https://www.kshb.com/sports/kelce-continues-to-build-hall-of-fame-resume-against-ravens |archive-date=October 17, 2021 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=KSHB |language=en}}</ref> In the Chiefs week 15 game against the Chargers, he set a career high for receiving yards in a game with 191 yards. He also caught two touchdowns, including the game-winning 34-yard touchdown in overtime.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 17, 2021 |title=Kelce's OT touchdown gives Chiefs 34–28 win over Chargers |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/game/_/gameId/401326537 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220201045322/https://www.espn.com/nfl/game/_/gameId/401326537 |archive-date=February 1, 2022 |access-date=February 2, 2022 |website=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> He was named AFC Offensive Player of the Week for his performance.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gordon |first=Grant |date=December 22, 2021 |title=Packers QB Aaron Rodgers, Chiefs TE Travis Kelce lead Players of the Week |url=https://www.nfl.com/news/players-of-the-week-2021-week-15-aaron-rodgers-travis-kelce |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220113012121/https://www.nfl.com/news/players-of-the-week-2021-week-15-aaron-rodgers-travis-kelce |archive-date=January 13, 2022 |access-date=February 2, 2022 |website=NFL.com}}</ref> The game also put him over 1,000 yards for the season, his NFL record (among tight ends) extending sixth consecutive 1,000-yard season. It also extended his record for most 1,000-yard seasons by a tight end with six. He was placed on the Reserve/COVID-19 list on December 20, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Brisco |first=Joshua |date=December 20, 2021 |title=Travis Kelce, Charvarius Ward, Harrison Butker Placed on Reserve/COVID-19 List |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/chiefs/news/kc-chiefs-te-travis-kelce-placed-on-reserve-covid-19-list |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211229200556/https://www.si.com/nfl/chiefs/news/kc-chiefs-te-travis-kelce-placed-on-reserve-covid-19-list |archive-date=December 29, 2021 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=Sports Illustrated Kansas City Chiefs News, Analysis and More |language=en}}</ref> He was activated on December 25, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |date=December 25, 2021 |title=Receiver Tyreek Hill, activated by Kansas City Chiefs, will play Week 16 against Pittsburgh Steelers |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/32936512/receiver-tyreek-hill-activated-kansas-city-chiefs-play-week-16-pittsburgh-steelers |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220125041054/https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/32936512/receiver-tyreek-hill-activated-kansas-city-chiefs-play-week-16-pittsburgh-steelers |archive-date=January 25, 2022 |access-date=February 2, 2022 |website=ESPN.com}}</ref> However, due to NFL protocols for [[COVID-19]], since he tested positive for the virus and did not test negative before the day of the game, he was ruled out for the Chiefs Week 16 game against the  Steelers. It was the first game he'd missed due to injury or illness since his rookie season.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |date=December 26, 2021 |title=Kansas City Chiefs TE Travis Kelce still in COVID-19 protocol; out vs. Pittsburgh Steelers |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/32939954/source-kansas-city-chiefs-te-travis-kelce-covid-19-protocol-vs-pittsburgh-steelers |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220125035751/https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/32939954/source-kansas-city-chiefs-te-travis-kelce-covid-19-protocol-vs-pittsburgh-steelers |archive-date=January 25, 2022 |access-date=February 2, 2022 |website=ESPN.com}}</ref> In the regular season-ending game against the Broncos, Kelce became the fastest tight end in NFL history to reach 9,000 career yards in just 127 games, a record also previously held by Gronkowski with 140 games.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Goldman |first=Charles |date=January 9, 2022 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce quickest at his position to 9,000 career receiving yards |url=https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2022/01/08/kansas-city-chiefs-travis-kelce-fastest-tight-end-to-9000-career-receiving-yards/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220109233752/https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2022/01/08/kansas-city-chiefs-travis-kelce-fastest-tight-end-to-9000-career-receiving-yards/ |archive-date=January 9, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=Chiefs Wire |language=en-US}}</ref> He finished the season with 92 receptions for 1,125 receiving yards and nine touchdowns. He was named Second-Team All-Pro by the AP, his sixth overall All-Pro selection. He was also named to his seventh consecutive Pro Bowl.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Goldman |first=Charles |date=December 20, 2021 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce selected for 7th consecutive Pro Bowl |url=https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2021/12/20/kansas-city-chiefs-travis-kelce-2022-pro-bowl-selection-seventh-consecutive-streak/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220203012255/https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2021/12/20/kansas-city-chiefs-travis-kelce-2022-pro-bowl-selection-seventh-consecutive-streak/ |archive-date=February 3, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=Chiefs Wire |language=en-US}}</ref>

In the [[2021–22 NFL playoffs#AFC: Kansas City Chiefs 42, Pittsburgh Steelers 21|Wild Card Round]] against the Pittsburgh Steelers, Kelce had five receptions for 108 yards and a receiving touchdown to go along with a two-yard touchdown pass to [[Byron Pringle]] in the 42–21 victory.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Wild Card – Pittsburgh Steelers at Kansas City Chiefs – January 16th, 2022 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201160kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220128104256/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201160kan.htm |archive-date=January 28, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref> In the [[2021 AFC Divisional playoff game (Buffalo–Kansas City)|Divisional Round]] against the Bills, he had eight receptions for 96 yards and the game-winning touchdown in the 42–36 overtime victory.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Divisional Round – Buffalo Bills at Kansas City Chiefs – January 23rd, 2022 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201230kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220130192305/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201230kan.htm |archive-date=January 30, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref> Kelce was wearing an [[NFL Films]] microphone for the game, and audio footage from the two offensive plays of the 13-second drive revealed that Kelce instructed [[Tyreek Hill]] to run the route which led to the success of the first completion, and revealed him suggesting to Mahomes that he might improvise his own route on the second offensive play if the Bills' defensive scheme didn't change. Prior to the snap, Mahomes realized Kelce's suggested improvised route would work and shouted "Do it, Kelce!", before finding his tight-end for a completion of 25 yards.<ref>{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Michael David |title=Travis Kelce was mic'd up, told teammates which routes would be open on game-tying drive |url=https://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2022/01/26/travis-kelce-was-micd-up-told-teammates-which-routes-would-be-open-on-game-tying-drive/ |website=NBCsports.com |date=January 26, 2022|access-date=January 26, 2022}}</ref> 

In the [[2021–22 NFL playoffs#AFC: Cincinnati Bengals 27, Kansas City Chiefs 24 (OT)|AFC Championship]] against the [[Cincinnati Bengals]], he had 10 receptions for 95 yards and a touchdown in the 27–24 overtime loss.<ref>{{Cite web |title=AFC Championship – Cincinnati Bengals at Kansas City Chiefs – January 30th, 2022 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201300kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220201165424/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201300kan.htm |archive-date=February 1, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref>

===2022 season: Second Super Bowl win===
[[File:President Joe Biden greets Kansas City Chiefs' President Mark Donovan, Head Coach Andy Reid and players Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce in the Oval Office of the White House on June 5, 2023 - P20230605AS-0902.jpg|thumb|Kelce (left) with President [[Joe Biden]] in 2023]]
{{See also|2022 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
In Week 5, Kelce had four receiving touchdowns in the 30–29 victory over the Raiders.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Las Vegas Raiders at Kansas City Chiefs – October 10th, 2022 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202210100kan.htm |access-date=October 11, 2022 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref> Kelce tied the franchise record for receiving touchdowns in a game.<ref name="FourTDs">{{Cite web |last=Grathoff |first=Pete |date=October 10, 2022 |title=KC Chiefs' Travis Kelce set a quirky NFL record with his four touchdown receptions |url=https://www.kansascity.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/for-petes-sake/article267135586.html |access-date=October 11, 2022 |website=The Kansas City Star}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=White |first=Peter |date=February 17, 2023 |title='SNL': Travis Kelce & Jenna Ortega Among Hosts For Three Back-To-Back Shows |url=https://deadline.com/2023/02/snl-travis-kelce-jenna-ortega-to-host-1235262841/ |access-date=February 17, 2023 |website=Deadline |language=en-US}}</ref> In the Chiefs' Week 11 game against the Chargers, he recorded his NFL record-breaking (among tight ends) 33rd 100-yard receiving game with 115 yards. He also scored three touchdowns, including the game-winning touchdown, his second straight season recording a game-winning touchdown against the Chargers.<ref name="Hundred yard games"/> In Week 14 against the Broncos, he became the fifth tight end in NFL history to have 10,000 receiving yards. He also officially recorded his seventh consecutive 1,000-yard season, extending his records (among tight ends) of consecutive 1,000-yard seasons and most overall 1,000 seasons.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teope |first=Herbie |date=December 12, 2022 |title=Chiefs' Travis Kelce achieves 2 notable career milestones on same play vs. Broncos |url=https://www.kansascity.com/sports/nfl/kansas-city-chiefs/article269880677.html |access-date=December 13, 2022 |website=KansasCity.com}}</ref> He finished the 2022 season with 110 receptions for 1,338 receiving yards and 12 receiving touchdowns.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2022 Game Log |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/2022/ |access-date=February 20, 2023 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref>
Kelce set a single-game NFL postseason record for a tight end with 14 receptions in a 27–20 victory over the Jaguars in the [[2022–23 NFL playoffs#AFC: Kansas City Chiefs 27, Jacksonville Jaguars 20|Divisional Round]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=DeArdo |first=Bryan |date=January 21, 2023 |title=2023 NFL playoffs: Chiefs' Travis Kelce breaks own postseason record in divisional round win vs. Jaguars |url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/2023-nfl-playoffs-chiefs-travis-kelce-breaks-own-postseason-record-in-divisional-round-win-vs-jaguars/ |access-date=February 20, 2023 |website=CBSSports.com |language=en}}</ref> He scored two receiving touchdowns in the game.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Divisional Round - Jacksonville Jaguars at Kansas City Chiefs - January 21st, 2023 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202301210kan.htm |access-date=February 20, 2023 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref> Kelce and the Chiefs appeared in [[Super Bowl LVII]] against the Eagles. Kelce's brother Jason played for the Eagles, making it the first Super Bowl to feature two brothers as players on opposing teams.<ref>{{cite web|last=McEvoy |first=Colin |title=The Ultimate Sibling Rivalry: 8 Sets of Brothers Who Faced Off in Sports Championships |work=[[Biography (TV program)|Biography]] |date=February 9, 2023 |url=https://www.biography.com/athletes/a42805051/brothers-who-have-faced-off-in-championships |access-date=February 12, 2023}}</ref> Kelce caught six passes for 81 yards and a touchdown as the Chiefs beat the Eagles 38–35 to win his second [[Super Bowl]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Super Bowl LVII - Philadelphia Eagles vs. Kansas City Chiefs - February 12th, 2023 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202302120phi.htm |access-date=February 20, 2023 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en}}</ref>

=== 2023 season ===
[[File:Travis Kelce KC Chiefs 2023 season.jpg|thumb|Kelce (center) before a 2023 game against the [[Denver Broncos]]]]
{{see also|2023 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
Kelce was inactive for the Chiefs' game against the [[Detroit Lions]] due to a knee injury he suffered earlier in the week. It was his first game missed due to an injury since his rookie season.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gordon |first=Grant |date=September 7, 2023 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce (knee) out for 2023 NFL Kickoff Game vs. Lions |url=https://www.nfl.com/news/chiefs-te-travis-kelce-knee-will-miss-2023-nfl-kickoff-game-vs-lions |access-date=September 27, 2023 |website=NFL.com |language=en-US}}</ref> Kelce made his season debut the following week against the Jaguars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2023 Stats per Game - NFL |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/player/gamelog/_/id/15847/travis-kelce |access-date=September 27, 2023 |website=ESPN |language=en}}</ref> In the Chiefs week 7 game against the Chargers, Kelce tied a career high with 12 receptions. He also had 179 receiving yards, the second highest of his career. In the Chiefs week 9 game against the Dolphins, he broke the Chiefs franchise record for career receiving yards.<ref name="ChiefsYards">{{cite web |title=Kelce sets Chiefs record for receiving yards |url=https://www.kctv5.com/2023/11/05/kelce-sets-franchise-record-receiving-yards/ |website=KCTV.com|date=November 5, 2023 }}</ref>

== Other ventures ==
===Charity work===
In 2015, Kelce started the ''Eighty-Seven & Running'' foundation to give mentoring, training, motivation, and opportunities to underprivileged youth.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Kerr |first=Jeff |date=October 27, 2021 |title=How Travis Kelce has used his record-setting play at tight end to raise money for underprivileged youth |url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/how-travis-kelce-has-used-his-record-setting-play-at-tight-end-to-raise-money-for-underprivileged-youth/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220203012211/https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/how-travis-kelce-has-used-his-record-setting-play-at-tight-end-to-raise-money-for-underprivileged-youth/ |archive-date=February 3, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=CBSSports.com |language=en}}</ref> For his charity work, he was the Chiefs' team nominee for the [[Walter Payton Man of the Year Award]] in 2020.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tight End Travis Kelce Named Chiefs Nominee for Walter Payton NFL Man of the Year Award Presented by Nationwide |url=https://www.chiefs.com/news/tight-end-travis-kelce-named-chiefs-nominee-for-walter-payton-nfl-man-of-the-yea |website=Chiefs.com}}</ref> 

===Television appearances===
In January 2016, Kelce starred in the [[E! Entertainment Television]] dating show ''Catching Kelce''.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |date=January 28, 2016 |title=Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce to have his own reality TV dating series |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/kansas-city-chiefs/post/_/id/15848/travis-kelce-to-have-his-own-reality-tv-dating-series |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129154645/http://espn.go.com/blog/kansas-city-chiefs/post/_/id/15848/travis-kelce-to-have-his-own-reality-tv-dating-series |archive-date=January 29, 2016 |access-date=January 30, 2016 |website=ESPN.com}}</ref> The winner picked by Kelce was Maya Benberry.<ref name=":1" /> In 2020, Kelce appeared as a fictionalized version of himself in the first episode of the comedy series ''[[Moonbase 8]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Spencer |first=Samuel |date=November 9, 2020 |title=Why Travis Kelce Appeared on Showtime's 'Moonbase 8' |url=https://www.newsweek.com/moonbase-8-showtime-travis-kelce-cameo-1545940 |access-date=October 24, 2023 |website=Newsweek |language=en}}</ref> 

Kelce was the host of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' on March 4, 2023.<ref name="snlmarch">{{cite web |last=Mitovich |first=Matt Webb |date=February 16, 2023 |title=''SNL'': Kansas City Chiefs' Travis Kelce, Jenna Ortega to Host in March |url=https://tvline.com/2023/02/16/travis-kelce-snl-host-jenna-ortega-saturday-night-live/ |access-date=February 16, 2023 |work=TVLine}}</ref> His brother Jason also made an appearance on that episode with their parents as audience members, and was also in a sketch with Kelce and ''SNL'' cast members [[Heidi Gardner]] and [[Chloe Fineman]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Tinico |first=Armando |date=March 5, 2023 |title=Travis Kelce Recalls Canceled E! Show 'Catching Kelce' In 'SNL' Monologue: "It Was A Little Embarrassing" |url=https://deadline.com/2023/03/travis-kelce-recalls-canceled-e-show-catching-kelce-snl-monologue-1235279373/ ===Podcast===
Kelce and his brother, Jason, launched a weekly [[podcast]] called ''New Heights with Jason and Travis Kelce'' in September 2022. In the podcast, they discuss the NFL, as well as each other's games. The show also occasionally features guest stars.<ref>{{cite web |title=New Heights with Jason and Travis Kelce |url=https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/new-heights-with-jason-and-travis-kelce/id1643745036 |access-date=December 7, 2022 |website=Apple Podcasts |publisher=Apple}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Easton Jr. |first=Ed |date=September 8, 2022 |title=Chiefs' Travis Kelce, Eagles' Jason Kelce launch new weekly podcast |url=https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2022/09/08/kansas-city-chiefs-philadelphia-eagles-travis-kelce-jason-kelce-new-heights-podcast/ |access-date=December 7, 2022 |website=Chiefs Wire |publisher=USA Today}}</ref> 

===Music===
Through his Super Bowl runs with the Chiefs, Kelce became known for reciting the chorus from the [[Beastie Boys]]' 1986 song "[[(You Gotta) Fight for Your Right (To Party!)]]" during team celebrations, first after the [[2019–20 NFL playoffs#AFC: Kansas City Chiefs 35, Tennessee Titans 24|2019 AFC Championship Game]] then again at the parade in Kansas City after clinching Super Bowl LIV. The Chiefs responded by making "Fight for Your Right" its touchdown song during games at [[Arrowhead Stadium]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Shapiro |first=Michael |date=January 19, 2020 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce Channels Beastie Boys in AFC Championship Celebration |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2020/01/20/travis-kelce-channels-beastie-boys-after-afc-championship |magazine=[[Sports Illustrated]] |access-date=February 20, 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Goldman |first=Charles |title=Reminder: Chiefs have a new touchdown song coming for 2020 |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |url=https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2020/05/15/kansas-city-chiefs-touchdown-song-you-gotta-fight-for-your-right-to-party-beastie-boys/ |access-date=February 20, 2023}}</ref> Kelce would continue the practice with the Chiefs' second championship in four years, adding a live performance of the song with [[Jimmy Fallon]] on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon|The Tonight Show]]''.<ref>{{cite news |date=February 17, 2023 |title=Travis Kelce: Epic Karaoke sesh w/ Fallon |newspaper=[[TMZ]] |url=https://www.tmz.com/2023/02/17/travis-kelce-belts-out-fight-for-your-right-with-jimmy-fallon-in-epic-karaoke-sesh/ |access-date=February 20, 2023}}</ref>

The two brothers sang a cover of "[[Fairytale of New York]]" (1987) by [[the Pogues]] featuring [[Kirsty MacColl]], titled "Fairytale of Philadelphia", which appeared on the 2023 album ''[[A Philly Special Christmas Special]]'';<ref>{{cite news |last=DeLuca |first=Dan |date=November 14, 2023 |title=Every new song from the Eagles' 'A Philly Special Christmas Special' reviewed. As they're released. |newspaper=The Philadelphia Inquirer |url=https://www.inquirer.com/entertainment/music/eagles-christmas-album-2023-reviews-20231102.html |access-date=November 18, 2023}}</ref> proceeds from the album benefit various charity institutions in Philadelphia. "Fairytale of Philadelphia" topped the US [[iTunes]] chart, following which the brothers thanked the [[Swifties]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Dailey |first=Hannah |date=November 22, 2023 |title=Jason and Travis Kelce Thank Taylor Swift & Swifties For Sending Christmas Single to No. 1 on iTunes |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/jason-travis-kelce-thank-swifties-christmas-single-1235508149/ |access-date=November 22, 2023 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref> The song further debuted at number five on the [[Digital Songs|''Billboard'' Digital Song Sales]] chart and number two on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Rock Digital Song Sales with 6,000 downloads sold in the first week, making the brothers ''Billboard''-charting artists.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Zellner |first=Xander |date=November 21, 2023 |title=10 First-Timers on Billboard's Charts This Week: Travis Kelce, Jason Kelce, The Red Clay Strays & More |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/travis-kelce-jason-kelce-billboard-charts-debut-1235502120/ |access-date=November 22, 2023 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref>

=== Cars ===
Kelce is an avid car collector.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gutierrez |first1=Lisa |last2=Grathoff |first2=Pete |date=September 27, 2023 |title=Here's the 'getaway car' Travis Kelce chose to whisk Taylor Swift away after Chiefs game |url=https://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article279773379.html |access-date=September 28, 2023 |publisher=The Kansas City Star |language=en}}</ref> In 2023, Kelce (as well as Patrick Mahomes) became an investor in the [[Alpine F1 Team|Alpine racing team]] of [[Formula One]].<ref>{{cite web |last=McDaniel |first=Mike |date=October 17, 2023 |title=Patrick Mahomes, Travis Kelce Become Investors in Alpine F1 Team |url=https://www.si.com/racing/2023/10/17/patrick-mahomes-travis-kelce-investors-alpine-f1-team |access-date=November 27, 2023 |publisher=Sports Illustrated |language=en}}</ref>

Kelce began dating singer-songwriter [[Taylor Swift]] in 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Blanchet |first=Brenton |date=November 20, 2023 |title=Travis Kelce Shares the Real Story of How Taylor Swift Romance Began in Wide-Ranging Interview |url=https://people.com/travis-kelce-shares-real-story-taylor-swift-romance-started-8404324 |access-date=November 20, 2023 |website=[[People (magazine)|People]] |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Aniftos |first=Rania |date=2023-11-20 |title=A Timeline of Taylor Swift & Travis Kelce's Relationship |url=https://www.billboard.com/lists/taylor-swift-travis-kelce-relationship-timeline/ |access-date=2023-11-20 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref> The highly publicized relationship had a considerable impact on NFL viewership; the Chiefs–[[Chicago Bears|Bears]] game, which Swift attended, drew the most television viewers of the weekend, while sales of Kelce's jersey and Chiefs home game tickets surged.<ref>{{cite web |last=Thomas |first=Carly |date=September 28, 2023 |title=The Taylor Swift Effect Is Very Real and It's Now Taking the Sports World by Storm |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lifestyle/lifestyle-news/taylor-swift-travis-kelce-impact-sports-nfl-ticket-sales-chiefs-game-viewership-1235604028/ |accessdate=September 29, 2023 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}}</ref> The NFL and [[NBC Sports|NBC]] used the relationship for social media content and to promote subsequent games.<ref>{{cite web |last=Dye |first=Natasha |date=September 29, 2023 |title=Sunday Night Football Debuts Taylor Swift-Themed Promo Ahead of Travis Kelce and Chiefs' Game — Watch! |url=https://people.com/sunday-night-football-debuts-taylor-swift-themed-promo-for-travis-kelce-chiefs-game-8285981 |accessdate=September 29, 2023 |work=[[People (magazine)|People]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last1=Porter |first1=Rick |last2=Weprin |first2=Alex |date=2023-10-12 |title=The NFL's Taylor Swift Era: Who Wins the Most? |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/business/business-news/nfl-taylor-swift-era-female-fans-1235614539/ |access-date=2023-11-20 |website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |language=en-US}}</ref> A Chiefs–[[New York Jets|Jets]] game that Swift attended averaged 27 million viewers, making it the most-watched Sunday-night television show since [[Super Bowl LVII]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Bell |first=BreAnna |date=October 2, 2023 |title=Chiefs-Jets NFL Game Hits 27 Million Viewers as Taylor Swift Makes Second Week Cheering on Travis Kelce |url=https://variety.com/2023/tv/news/chiefs-jets-nfl-taylor-swift-travis-kelce-ratings-1235742304/ |access-date=October 6, 2023 |website=Variety |language=en-US}}</ref>

In addition to owning a home in the [[Kansas City metropolitan area|Kansas City area]], Kelce also owns a condo in [[Orlando, Florida]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Montanez |first=Abby |date=2023-10-20 |title=Travis Kelce Just Dropped $6 Million on a Kansas City Hideaway Because of Taylor Swift |url=https://robbreport.com/shelter/celebrity-homes/travis-kelce-buys-kansas-city-hideaway-1235374663/ |access-date=2023-12-02 |website=[[Robb Report]] |language=en-US}}</ref>
